title: The Altar and Court
shortSummary: Exodus 27 details God's instructions to Moses for constructing the altar of burnt offering and the surrounding court of the tabernacle. These precise specifications emphasize holiness, worship order, and the continual presence of God among His people. The chapter concludes with the command for pure olive oil to keep the lamp burning perpetually, symbolizing God's enduring light.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Exodus and Wilderness Tabernacle Instructions

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who receives and conveys God's detailed instructions for the tabernacle's construction.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The high priest appointed to oversee the lamp and the service before the LORD as commanded in this chapter.

keyCharacters.name: The Children of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The nation commanded to bring pure olive oil for the continual light and to participate in the tabernacle's worship.

definitions.definition: A durable, dense wood from the acacia tree, used for sacred furniture in the tabernacle.
An ancient measurement roughly equal to 18 inches, used to specify dimensions in the tabernacle.
A metal alloy used extensively in the tabernacle vessels and fittings, symbolizing judgment and purification.
A high-quality, finely woven fabric used for the tabernacle curtains and hangings, representing purity.

outline.heading: The Altar of Burnt Offering
outline.description: God commands the construction of the altar with precise dimensions and materials, emphasizing its holiness and function in worship. The altar is to be made of shittim wood overlaid with brass, equipped with utensils for sacrifice, symbolizing atonement and God's provision for sin.

outline.heading: The Court of the Tabernacle
outline.description: Instructions are given for the court's dimensions, hangings, pillars, and sockets, creating a sacred space for worship outside the tabernacle. The use of fine linen, brass, silver, and specific measurements highlights God's order and the separation between the holy and the common.

outline.heading: The Command for Pure Olive Oil
outline.description: God commands the Israelites to bring pure olive oil for the lamp to burn continually before the LORD. Aaron and his sons are appointed to maintain this perpetual light, symbolizing God's eternal presence and guidance for His people.

application: Obey God’s detailed instructions in worship as an expression of reverence and holiness.
Maintain a continual spiritual 'light' in your life through prayer, Scripture, and dependence on God.
Recognize the importance of purity and dedication in your service to God, following the example of Aaron and his sons.
Value the order and structure God provides in worship as a reflection of His holy character.

keyVerses.text: And thou shalt make an altar of shittim wood, five cubits long, and five cubits broad; the altar shall be foursquare: and the height thereof shall be three cubits.
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces the altar’s construction, highlighting God’s precise design for worship and atonement.

keyVerses.text: And thou shalt command the children of Israel, that they bring thee pure oil olive beaten for the light, to cause the lamp to burn always.
keyVerses.significance: This verse commands the continual burning of the lamp, symbolizing God’s eternal presence and guidance.

keyVerses.text: In the tabernacle of the congregation without the vail, which is before the testimony, Aaron and his sons shall order it from evening to morning before the LORD: it shall be a statute for ever unto their generations on the behalf of the children of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes the priestly responsibility to maintain the lamp, underscoring faithful service and God's enduring covenant.
